title: XML Schema Complex Type - Text Elements

metadata.title: W3Schools.com

content.text: A complex text-only element can contain text and attributes.
content.html: A complex text-only element can contain text and attributes.

content.text: This type contains only simple content (text and attributes), therefore we add a simpleContent element around the content. When using simple content, you must define an extension OR a restriction within the simpleContent element, like this:
content.html: This type contains only simple content (text and attributes), therefore we add a simpleContent element around the content. When using simple content, you must define an extension OR a restriction within the simpleContent element, like this:

content.code_html:
<xs:element name="somename">
  <xs:complexType>
    <xs:simpleContent>
      <xs:extension base="basetype">
        ....
        ....
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:simpleContent>
  </xs:complexType>
</xs:element>

OR

<xs:element name="somename">
  <xs:complexType>
    <xs:simpleContent>
      <xs:restriction base="basetype">
        ....
        ....
      </xs:restriction>
    </xs:simpleContent>
  </xs:complexType>
</xs:element>

content.text: Tip: Use the extension/restriction element to expand or to limit the base simple type for the element.
content.html: Tip: Use the extension/restriction element to expand or to limit the base simple type for the element.

content.text: Here is an example of an XML element, "shoesize", that contains text-only:
content.html: Here is an example of an XML element, "shoesize", that contains text-only:

content.code_html: <shoesize country="france">35</shoesize>

content.text: The following example declares a complexType, "shoesize". The content is defined as an integer value, and the "shoesize" element also contains an attribute named "country":
content.html: The following example declares a complexType, "shoesize". The content is defined as an integer value, and the "shoesize" element also contains an attribute named "country":

content.code_html:
<xs:element name="shoesize">
  <xs:complexType>
    <xs:simpleContent>
      <xs:extension base="xs:integer">
        <xs:attribute name="country" type="xs:string" />
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:simpleContent>
  </xs:complexType>
</xs:element>

content.text: We could also give the complexType element a name, and let the "shoesize" element have a type attribute that refers to the name of the complexType (if you use this method, several elements can refer to the same complex type):
content.html: We could also give the complexType element a name, and let the "shoesize" element have a type attribute that refers to the name of the complexType (if you use this method, several elements can refer to the same complex type):

content.code:
<xs:element name="shoesize" type="shoetype"/>


<xs:complexType name="shoetype">


<xs:simpleContent>


<xs:extension base="xs:integer">


<xs:attribute name="country" type="xs:string" />


</xs:extension>


</xs:simpleContent>

</xs:complexType>
content.code_html:
<xs:element name="shoesize" type="shoetype"/>

<xs:complexType name="shoetype">
  <xs:simpleContent>
    <xs:extension base="xs:integer">
      <xs:attribute name="country" type="xs:string" />
    </xs:extension>
  </xs:simpleContent>
</xs:complexType>
